00043 ## @package pyp_utils
00044 # pyp_utils contains a set of procedures for creating and operating on PyPedal pedigrees.
00045 # This includes routines for reordering and renumbering pedigrees, as well as for modifying
00046 # pedigrees.
00047 
00048 import copy, logging, numpy, os, string, sys, time
00049 import pyp_demog
00050 import pyp_metrics
00051 import pyp_newclasses

00053 ##
00054 # set_ancestor_flag() loops through a pedigree to build a dictionary of all of the parents
00055 # in the pedigree.  It then sets the ancestor flags for the parents.  set_ancestor_flag()
00056 # expects a reordered and renumbered pedigree as input!
00057 # @param pedobj A PyPedal NewPedigree object.
00058 # @retval 0 for failure and 1 for success.
00059 def set_ancestor_flag(pedobj):
00060     """
00061     set_ancestor_flag() loops through a pedigree to build a dictionary of all of the
00062     parents in the pedigree.  It then sets the ancestor flags for the parents.
00063     set_ancestor_flag() expects a reordered and renumbered pedigree as input!
00064     """
00065     try:
00066         parents = {}        # holds a list of animals who are parents
00067         l = len(pedobj.pedigree)
00068         if l < 2:
00069             print '[ERROR]: pedobj.pedigree only contains one record -- nothing to do in set_ancestor_flag()!'
00070             return
00071 
00072         pedobj.pedigree.reverse()     # We want to go from young to old.
00073         for i in xrange(l):
00074             # Put the animalIDs of the animals parents in the parents list if
00075             # they are known and are not already in the dictionary.
00076             if pedobj.kw['messages'] == 'debug':
00077                 print '[DEBUG]:\t\tanimal: %s\tsire: %s\tdam: %s' % (pedobj.pedigree[i].animalID,pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID,pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)
00078             #if int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID) != 0:
00079             if pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00080                 try:
00081                     _i = parents[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)]
00082                 except:
00083                     parents[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)] = int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)
00084                     pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)-1].ancestor = 1
00085 
00086             #if int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID) != 0:
00087             if pedobj.pedigree[i].damID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00088                 try:
00089                     _i = parents[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)]
00090                 except:
00091                     parents[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)] = int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)
00092                     pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)-1].ancestor = 1
00093         pedobj.pedigree.reverse()     # Put pedobj.pedigree back the way it was -- pass-by-reference, don't you know!
00094 
00095         if pedobj.kw['file_io']:
00096             try:
00097                 a_outputfile = '%s%s%s' % (pedobj.kw['filetag'],'_ancestors','.dat')
00098                 aout = open(a_outputfile,'w')
00099                 aout.write('# FILE: %s\n' % a_outputfile)
00100                 aout.write('# ANCESTOR list produced by PyPedal.\n')
00101                 for l in parents.keys():
00102                     aout.write('%s\n' % l)
00103                 aout.close()
00104                 logging.info('pyp_utils/set_ancestor_flag() wrote file %s.' % (a_outputfile))
00105             except:
00106                 logging.error('pyp_utils/set_ancestor_flag() could not write file %s.' % (a_outputfile))
00107 
00108         return 1
00109 
00110     except:
00111         a_outputfile = '%s%s%s' % (pedobj.kw['filetag'],'_ancestors','.dat')
00112         logging.error('pyp_utils/set_ancestor_flag() could not write file %s.' % (a_outputfile))
00113         return 0
00114 
00115 ##
00116 # set_generation() Works through a pedigree to infer the generation to which an animal
00117 # belongs based on founders belonging to generation 1.  The igen assigned to an animal
00118 # as the larger of sire.igen+1 and dam.igen+1.  This routine assumes that myped is
00119 # reordered and renumbered.
00120 # @param pedobj A PyPedal NewPedigree object.
00121 # @retval 0 for failure and 1 for success.
00122 def set_generation(pedobj):
00123     """
00124     set_generation() Works through a pedigree to infer the generation to which an animal
00125     belongs based on founders belonging to generation 1.  The igen assigned to an animal
00126     as the larger of sire.igen+1 and dam.igen+1.  This routine assumes that myped is
00127     reordered and renumbered.
00128     """
00129     try:
00130         if pedobj.kw['messages'] == 'debug':
00131             print '[NOTE]: pyp_utils/set_generation() assigning inferred generations in pedigree %s.' % (pedobj.kw['pedname'])
00132         for i in range(pedobj.metadata.num_records):
00133             #if int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID) == 0 and int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID) == 0:
00134             if pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent'] and  pedobj.pedigree[i].damID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00135                 if pedobj.kw['gen_coeff']:
00136                     pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff = 1.
00137                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = int(round(pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff))
00138                 else:
00139                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = 1
00140             #elif int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID) == 0:
00141             elif pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00142                 if pedobj.kw['gen_coeff']:
00143                     pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff = ( pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)-1].gencoeff / 2. ) + 1.
00144                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = int(round(pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff))
00145                 else:
00146                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)-1].igen + 1
00147             #elif int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID) == 0:
00148             elif pedobj.pedigree[i].damID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00149                 if pedobj.kw['gen_coeff']:
00150                     pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff = ( pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)-1].gencoeff / 2. ) + 1.
00151                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = int(round(pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff))
00152                 else:
00153                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)-1].igen + 1
00154             else:
00155                 if pedobj.kw['gen_coeff']:
00156                     pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff = ( pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)-1].gencoeff + pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)-1].gencoeff / 2. ) + 1.
00157                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = int(round(pedobj.pedigree[i].gencoeff))
00158                 else:
00159                     pedobj.pedigree[i].igen = max(pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].sireID)-1].igen + 1,pedobj.pedigree[int(pedobj.pedigree[i].damID)-1].igen + 1)
00160         logging.info('pyp_utils/set_generation() assigned inferred generations in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00161         return 1
00162     except:
00163         logging.error('pyp_utils/set_generation() was unable to assign inferred generations in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00164         return 0
00165 
00166 ##
00167 # set_age() Computes ages for all animals in a pedigree based on the global
00168 # BASE_DEMOGRAPHIC_YEAR defined in pyp_demog.py.  If the by is unknown, the
00169 # inferred generation is used.  If the inferred generation is unknown, the
00170 # age is set to -999.
00171 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree object.
00172 # @retval 0 for failure and 1 for success.
00173 def set_age(pedobj):
00174     """
00175     set_age() Computes ages for all animals in a pedigree based on the global
00176     BASE_DEMOGRAPHIC_YEAR defined in pyp_demog.py.  If the by is unknown, the
00177     inferred generation is used.  If the inferred generation is unknown, the
00178     age is set to -999.
00179     """
00180     try:
00181         if pedobj.kw['messages'] == 'debug':
00182             print '[NOTE]: pyp_utils/set_age() assigning inferred ages in pedigree %s.' % (pedobj.kw['pedname'])
00183         l = len(pedobj.pedigree)
00184         for i in range(l):
00185             if pedobj.pedigree[i].by == -999 and pedobj.pedigree[i].igen == -999:
00186                 pedobj.pedigree[i].age = -999
00187             elif pedobj.pedigree[i].by == -999 and pedobj.pedigree[i].igen != -999:
00188                 pedobj.pedigree[i].age = pedobj.pedigree[i].igen
00189             else:
00190                 pedobj.pedigree[i].age = pedobj.pedigree[i].by - pyp_demog.BASE_DEMOGRAPHIC_YEAR
00191         logging.info('pyp_utils/set_age() assigned ages in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00192         return 1
00193     except:
00194         logging.error('pyp_utils/set_age() was unable to assign ages in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00195         return 0
00196 
00197 ##
00198 # set_species() assigns a specie to every animal in the pedigree.
00199 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree object.
00200 # @param species A PyPedal string.
00201 # @retval 0 for failure and 1 for success.
00202 def set_species(pedobj, species='u'):
00203     """
00204     set_species() assigns a specie to every animal in the pedigree.
00205     """
00206     try:
00207         if pedobj.kw['messages'] == 'debug':
00208             print '[NOTE]: pyp_utils/set_species() assigning specie %s to all animals in pedigree %s.' % (species, pedobj.kw['pedname'])
00209         l = len(pedobj.pedigree)
00210         for i in range(l):
00211             if len(species) > 0:
00212                 pedobj.pedigree[i].species = species
00213             else:
00214                 pedobj.pedigree[i].species = 'u'
00215         logging.info('pyp_utils/set_species() assigned a specie in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00216         return 1
00217     except:
00218         logging.error('pyp_utils/set_age() was unable to assign ages in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00219         return 0
00220 
00221 ##
00222 # assign_sexes() assigns a sex to every animal in the pedigree using sire and daughter lists for improved accuracy.
00223 # @param pedobj A renumbered and reordered PyPedal pedigree object.
00224 # @retval 0 for failure and 1 for success.
00225 def assign_sexes(pedobj):
00226     """
00227     assign_sexes() assigns a sex to every animal in the pedigree using sire and daughter
00228     lists for improved accuracy.
00229     """
00230     try:
00231         if pedobj.kw['messages'] == 'verbose':
00232             print '[NOTE]: pyp_utils/assign_sexes() assigning a sex to all animals in pedigree %s.' % (pedobj.kw['pedname'])
00233         for _m in pedobj.pedigree:
00234             if _m.sireID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent'] and  _m.damID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00235                 pass
00236             elif _m.sireID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00237                 if pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sex != 'f':
00238                     if pedobj.kw['debug_messages']:
00239                         print '\t\tAnimal %s sex changed from\t%s\tto\tf' % (_m.damID,pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sex)
00240                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sex = 'f'
00241             elif _m.damID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00242                 if pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sex != 'm':
00243                     if pedobj.kw['debug_messages']:
00244                         print '\t\tAnimal %s sex changed from\t%s\tto\tm' % (_m.sireID,pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sex)
00245                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sex = 'm'
00246             else:
00247                 if pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sex != 'f':
00248                     if pedobj.kw['debug_messages']:
00249                         print '\t\tAnimal %s sex changed from\t%s\tto\tf' % (_m.damID,pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sex)
00250                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sex = 'f'
00251                 if pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sex != 'm':
00252                     if pedobj.kw['debug_messages']:
00253                         print '\t\tAnimal %s sex changed from\t%s\tto\tm' % (_m.sireID,pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sex)
00254                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sex = 'm'
00255         logging.info('pyp_utils/assign_sexes() assigned sexes in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00256         return 1
00257     except:
00258         logging.error('pyp_utils/assign_sexes() was unable to assign sexes in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00259         return 0
00260 
00261 ##
00262 # assign_offspring() assigns offspring to their parent(s)'s unknown sex offspring list (well, dictionary).
00263 # @param pedobj An instance of a NewPedigree object.
00264 # @retval 0 for failure and 1 for success.
00265 def assign_offspring(pedobj):
00266     """
00267     assign_offspring() assigns offspring to their parent(s)'s unknown sex offspring list
00268     (well, dictionary).
00269     """
00270     try:
00271         if pedobj.kw['messages'] == 'debug':
00272             print '[NOTE]: pyp_utils/assign_offspring() assigning offspring to all parents in pedigree %s.' % (species, pedobj.kw['pedname'])
00273         for _m in pedobj.pedigree:
00274             pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.animalID)-1].sons = {}
00275             pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.animalID)-1].daus = {}
00276             pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.animalID)-1].unks = {}
00277         if 'x' not in pedobj.kw['pedformat']:
00278             for _m in pedobj.pedigree:
00279                 if _m.sireID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent'] and _m.damID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00280                     pass
00281                 elif _m.sireID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00282                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].unks[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00283                 elif _m.damID == pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00284                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].unks[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00285                 else:
00286                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].unks[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00287                     pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].unks[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00288         else:
00289             # We purportedly know animal sexes, so put the offspring in the correct
00290             # lists.
00291             for _m in pedobj.pedigree:
00292                 if _m.sex == 'm' or _m.sex == 'M':
00293                     if _m.sireID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00294                         #print 'Sire %s has son %s' % (_m.sireID, _m.animalID)
00295                         pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].sons[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00296                     if _m.damID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00297                         #print 'Dam %s has son %s' % (_m.damID, _m.animalID)
00298                         pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].sons[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00299                 elif _m.sex == 'f' or _m.sex == 'F':
00300                     if _m.sireID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00301                         #print 'Sire %s has daughter %s' % (_m.sireID, _m.animalID)
00302                         pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].daus[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00303                     if _m.damID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00304                         #print 'Dam %s has daughter %s' % (_m.sireID, _m.animalID)
00305                         pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].daus[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00306                 else:
00307                     if _m.sireID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00308                         #print 'Sire %s has unknown %s' % (_m.sireID, _m.animalID)
00309                         pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.sireID)-1].unks[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00310                     if _m.damID != pedobj.kw['missing_parent']:
00311                         #print 'Dam %s has unknown %s' % (_m.sireID, _m.animalID)
00312                         pedobj.pedigree[int(_m.damID)-1].unks[_m.animalID] = _m.animalID
00313         logging.info('pyp_utils/assign_offspring() assigned offspring in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00314         return 1
00315     except:
00316         logging.error('pyp_utils/assign_offspring() was unable to assign offspring in pedigree %s' % (pedobj.kw['pedname']))
00317         return 0
00318 
00319 ##
00320 # assign_upg() assigns pseudo-parents to animals with unknown (missing) parents. The
00321 # pseudo-parents can bbe used as Westell groups in an animal model.
00322 # @param pedobj An instance of a PyPedal NewPedigree object.
00323 # @retval None
00324 def assign_upg(pedobj):
00325     """
00326     assign_upg() assigns pseudo-parents to animals with unknown (missing) parents. The
00327     pseudo-parents can bbe used as Westell groups in an animal model.
00328     """
00329     for p in pedobj:
00330         if pedobk.kw['pedformat'] == 'asd' or  pedobk.kw['pedformat'] == 'ASD':
00331         p.sireID = -999999
00332         p.sireName = 'Sire_UPG'
00333     else:
00334             pass

00336 ##
00337 # reorder() renumbers a pedigree such that parents precede their offspring in the
00338 # pedigree.  In order to minimize overhead as much as is reasonably possible,
00339 # a list of animal IDs that have already been seen is kept.  Whenever a parent
00340 # that is not in the seen list is encountered, the offspring of that parent is
00341 # moved to the end of the pedigree.  This should ensure that the pedigree is
00342 # properly sorted such that all parents precede their offspring.  myped is
00343 # reordered in place.  reorder() is VERY slow, but I am pretty sure that it works
00344 # correctly.
00345 # @note Deprecated
00346 # @param myped A PyPedal pedigree object.
00347 # @param filetag A descriptor prepended to output file names.
00348 # @param io Indicates whether or not to write the reordered pedigree to a file (yes|no).
00349 # @param missingparent Indicates the value used to indicate a missing parent.
00350 # @param debug Toggles debugging messages on and off.
00351 # @param max_rounds Maximum times to iterate through a pedigree trying to reorder it.
00352 # @retval A reordered PyPedal pedigree.
00353 def reorder(myped, filetag='_reordered_', io='no', missingparent=0, debug=0, max_rounds=100):
00354     """
00355     Renumber a pedigree such that parents precede their offspring in the
00356     pedigree.  In order to minimize overhead as much as is reasonably possible,
00357     a list of animal IDs that have already been seen is kept.  Whenever a parent
00358     that is not in the seen list is encountered, the offspring of that parent is
00359     moved to the end of the pedigree.  This should ensure that the pedigree is
00360     properly sorted such that all parents precede their offspring.  myped is
00361     reordered in place.
00362 
00363     reorder() is VERY slow, but I am pretty sure that it works correctly.
00364     """
00365     l = len(myped)
00366     _passnum = 1     # we are going to count how many passes through the
00367                      # pedigree are needed to sort it.
00368     _moved_counter = 0
00369     _last_founder = 0
00370 
00371     # These are "Avoiding dots..." optimizations to eliminate/reduce
00372     # function reevaluation as described in the PythonSpeed/PerformanceTips
00373     # wiki at:
00374     # http://wiki.python.org/moin/PythonSpeed/PerformanceTips
00375     mypedins = myped.insert
00376     mypedidx = myped.index
00377     copycopy = copy.copy
00378 
00379     # Move all founders to the start of the pedigree
00380     founderlist = []
00381     for i in xrange(l):
00382         if myped[i].sireID == missingparent and myped[i].damID == missingparent:
00383             founderlist.append(i)
00384     # Founderlist stores the indices of founders. We go from left-to-right
00385     # to preserve the indices of founders at the end of the pedigree.
00386     founderlist.sort()
00387     #print 'founderlist: ', founderlist
00388     for f in founderlist:
00389         # Make a copy of the founder
00390         _founder = copycopy(myped[f])
00391         # Delete the original the original founder record
00392         del myped[f]
00393         # Prepend the copy of the founder record to the pedigree
00394         mypedins(0, _founder)
00395 
00396     # order is a list that is used to keep track of each animal's
00397     # position in the pedigree. IT needs to be updated after any
00398     # movement of founders and before the main loop begins so that
00399     # the correct indices are use for sires and dams. If you don't
00400     # have it in the correct place you get duplication of records,
00401     # inexplicably incorrect parent information, etc.
00402     orderdict, orderbackdict = {}, {}
00403     for i in xrange(len(myped)):
00404         orderdict[myped[i].animalID] = i
00405         orderbackdict[i] = myped[i].animalID
00406 
00407     while(1):
00408         if debug:
00409             print '='*70
00410             print '[DEBUG]: Pass %s' % ( _passnum )
00411         # Loop over the pedigree.  Whenever a parent follows their offspring
00412         # in the pedigree, move the child to the end of the pedigree.
00413         # Continue until all parents precede their offspring.
00414         #for i in xrange(l):
00415         if debug: print '_last_founder: ', _last_founder
00416         for i in xrange(l):
00417         #for i in xrange(_last_founder,l):
00418             #
00419             # Since attribute access is slower than local variable access we're going
00420             # to put some IDs in local variables here in the inner loop.
00421             #
00422             animalid = myped[i].animalID
00423             sireid = myped[i].sireID
00424             damid = myped[i].damID
00425             animalname = myped[i].name
00426             sirename = myped[i].sireName
00427             damname = myped[i].damName
00428 
00429             #print animalid, animalname, sireid, sirename, damid, damname
00430 
00431             _anidx = orderdict[animalid]
00432 
00433             if str(sireid) != str(missingparent) and str(damid) != str(missingparent):
00434                 _maxidx = max(orderdict[sireid], orderdict[damid])
00435             elif str(sireid) == str(missingparent) and str(damid) != str(missingparent):
00436                 _maxidx = orderdict[damid]
00437             elif str(sireid) != str(missingparent) and str(damid) == str(missingparent):
00438                 _maxidx = orderdict[sireid]
00439             else:
00440                 # Handle founders
00441                 _maxidx = -1
00442             if _anidx < _maxidx:
00443                 _a = copycopy(myped[i])
00444                 # Insert the animal ahead of its parents.
00445                 mypedins(_maxidx+1, _a)
00446                 #if debug:
00447                     #print 'Moving animal %s (%s) ahead of its parents (sire %s (%s), dam %s (%s).' % ( animalid, animalname, sireid, sirename, damid, damname )
00448                     #print '\tStarting animal index: ', _anidx
00449                     #print '\tNew animal index: ', _maxidx+1
00450                     #if str(sireid) != str(missingparent):
00451                         #print '\tNew sire index:   ', orderdict[sireid]
00452                     #if str(damid) != str(missingparent):
00453                         #print '\tNew dam index:    ', orderdict[damid]
00454                 # Delete the original pedigree entry
00455                 del myped[i]
00456                 for idx in xrange(_anidx, _maxidx):
00457                     anmov = orderbackdict[idx+1]
00458                     orderdict[anmov] = idx
00459                     orderbackdict[idx]  = anmov
00460                 orderdict[animalid] = _maxidx
00461                 orderbackdict[_maxidx] = animalid
00462                 if debug:
00463                     print 'Moved animal %s (%s) ahead of its parents (sire %s (%s), dam %s (%s).' % ( animalid, animalname, sireid, sirename, damid, damname )
00464                     print '\tNew animal index: ', orderdict[animalid]
00465                     if str(sireid) != str(missingparent):
00466                         print '\tNew sire index:   ', orderdict[sireid]
00467                     if str(damid) != str(missingparent):
00468                         print '\tNew dam index:    ', orderdict[damid]
00469                 # Delete the animal's original (first) record in the pedigree file.
00470                 del _a, animalid, sireid, damid, animalname, sirename, damname
00471                 del _anidx, _maxidx
00472                 _moved_counter = _moved_counter + 1
00473 
00474             #elif str(sireid) == str(missingparent) and str(damid) == str(missingparent):
00475                 #if _anidx > 0:
00476                     #_a = copycopy(myped[i])
00477                     ## SO NOT move this delete statement or you'll break code!
00478                     ## The list is being altered by adding items to the head,
00479                     ## so we need to delete the originalrecord before prepending
00480                     ## the list. If not, you'll start losing records to deletion
00481                     ## during reordering.
00482                     #del myped[i]
00483                     #mypedins(_last_founder, _a)
00484                     #for idx in xrange(_last_founder, _anidx):
00485                         #anmov = orderbackdict[idx]
00486                         #orderdict[anmov] = idx+1
00487                         #orderbackdict[idx+1] = anmov
00488                     #orderdict[animalid] = _last_founder
00489                     #orderbackdict[_last_founder] = animalid
00490                     #if debug:
00491                         #print 'Moved founder %s (%s) to position %s in the pedigree (sire %s (%s), dam %s (%s).' % ( animalid, animalname, _last_founder, sireid, sirename, damid, damname )
00492                         #print '\tNew animal index: ', orderdict[animalid]
00493                         #if str(sireid) != str(missingparent):
00494                             #print '\tNew sire index:   ', orderdict[sireid]
00495                         #if str(damid) != str(missingparent):
00496                             #print '\tNew dam index:    ', orderdict[damid]
00497                     ## Delete the animal's original (first) record in the pedigree file.
00498                     #del _a, animalid, sireid, damid, animalname, sirename, damname
00499                     #del _anidx, _maxidx
00500                     #_moved_counter = _moved_counter + 1
00501                 #else:
00502                     #if debug:
00503                         #print 'Animal %s (%s) is already at the beginning of the pedigree' % ( animalid, animalname )
00504                 #_last_founder = _last_founder + 1
00505 
00506             else:
00507                 pass
00508 
00509         if debug:
00510             for m in myped:
00511                 print m.animalID, m.name, m.sireID, m.sireName, m.damID, m.damName
00512 
00513         if _moved_counter == 0:
00514             break
00515         if _passnum == max_rounds:
00516             logging.error('pyp_utils/reorder() was unable to reorder the pedigree in %s rounds. Subsequent calculations that depend on the pedigree being correctly reordered may produce incorrect answers.' % ( _passnum ))
00517             print '[ERROR]: pyp_utils/reorder() was unable to reorder the pedigree in %s rounds. Subsequent calculations that depend on the pedigree being correctly reordered may produce incorrect answers.' % ( _passnum )
00518             break
00519         else:
00520             _passnum = _passnum + 1
00521             _moved_counter = 0
00522 
00523     if io == 'yes':
00524         # Write the reordered pedigree to a file and return the ordered pedigree.
00525         # Note that the reordered pedigree is currently only writte in the 'asd'
00526         # format, regardless of the format of the original file.
00527         a_outputfile = '%s%s%s' % (filetag,'_reordered','.ped')
00528         aout = open(a_outputfile,'w')
00529         aname = '# FILE: %s\n' % (a_outputfile)
00530         aout.write(aname)
00531         aout.write('# REORDERED pedigree produced by PyPedal.\n')
00532         aout.write('% asd\n')
00533         for l in range(len(myped)):
00534             aout.write('%s,%s,%s\n' % myped[l].animalID,myped[l].sireID,myped[l].damID)
00535         aout.close()
00536         del order
00537 
00538     return myped
00539 
00540 ##
00541 # fast_reorder() renumbers a pedigree such that parents precede their offspring in
00542 # the pedigree.  In order to minimize overhead as much as is reasonably possible,
00543 # a list of animal IDs that have already been seen is kept.  Whenever a parent
00544 # that is not in the seen list is encountered, the offspring of that parent is
00545 # moved to the end of the pedigree.  This should ensure that the pedigree is
00546 # properly sorted such that all parents precede their offspring.  myped is
00547 # reordered in place.  fast_reorder() uses dictionaries to renumber the pedigree
00548 # based on paddedIDs.
00549 # @param myped A PyPedal pedigree object.
00550 # @param filetag A descriptor prepended to output file names.
00551 # @param io Indicates whether or not to write the reordered pedigree to a file (yes|no).
00552 # @param debug Flag to indicate whether or not debugging messages are written to STDOUT.
00553 # @retval A reordered PyPedal pedigree.
00554 def fast_reorder(myped,filetag='_new_reordered_',io='no',debug=0):
00555     """
00556     Renumber a pedigree such that parents precede their offspring in the
00557     pedigree.  In order to minimize overhead as much as is reasonably possible,
00558     a list of animal IDs that have already been seen is kept.  Whenever a parent
00559     that is not in the seen list is encountered, the offspring of that parent is
00560     moved to the end of the pedigree.  This should ensure that the pedigree is
00561     properly sorted such that all parents precede their offspring.  myped is
00562     reordered in place.
00563 
00564     reorder() is VERY slow, but I am pretty sure that it works correctly.  fast_reorder()
00565     appears to be VERY fast, but I am not sure if it works correctly all of the time or
00566     not.  Use this procedure at your own risk!
00567     """
00568 
00569     l = len(myped)
00570     idlist = []
00571     animalmap = {}
00572     # <kludge>
00573     myped.reverse()
00574     # </kludge>
00575     if debug == 1:
00576         print '\tPedigree contains %s animals.' % (l)
00577         print '\tMaking a dictionary of animal objects'
00578         print '\tMaking a list of padded animal IDs'
00579     for i in range(l):
00580         if debug == 1:
00581             print '\tDEBUG\tID %s: %s = %s %s %s' % (i,myped[i].animalID,myped[i].paddedID,myped[i].sireID,myped[i].damID)
00582         animalmap[myped[i].paddedID] = myped[i]
00583         idlist.append(int(myped[i].paddedID))
00584     myped = []
00585     l = len(idlist)
00586     if debug == 1:
00587         print '[DEBUG]: %s elements in idlist' % (l)
00588         print '[DEBUG]: Printing reordered pedigree...'
00589     for i in range(len(idlist)):
00590         myped.append(animalmap[str(idlist[i])])
00591     if debug == 1:
00592         print '\t[DEBUG]:\tID %s: %s = %s' % (i,myped[i].animalID,myped[i].paddedID)
00593     if io == 'yes':
00594         # Write the reordered pedigree to a file and return the ordered pedigree.
00595         # Note that the reordered pedigree is currently only written in the 'asd'
00596         # format, regardless of the format of the original file.
00597         a_outputfile = '%s%s%s' % (filetag,'_reord','.ped')
00598         aout = open(a_outputfile,'w')
00599         aname = '# FILE: %s\n' % (a_outputfile)
00600         aout.write(aname)
00601         aout.write('# REORDERED pedigree produced by PyPedal using fast_reorder().\n')
00602         aout.write('% asd\n')
00603         for l in range(len(myped)):
00604             aout.write('%s,%s,%s\n' % myped[l].animalID,myped[l].sireID,myped[l].damID)
00605         aout.close()
00606     return myped
00607 
00608 ##
00609 # renumber() takes a pedigree as input and renumbers it such that the oldest
00610 # animal in the pedigree has an ID of '1' and the n-th animal has an ID of 'n'.  If the
00611 # pedigree is not ordered from oldest to youngest such that all offspring precede their
00612 # offspring, the pedigree will be reordered.  The renumbered pedigree is written to disc in
00613 # 'asd' format and a map file that associates sequential IDs with original IDs is also
00614 # written.
00615 # @param myped A PyPedal pedigree object.
00616 # @param filetag A descriptor prepended to output file names.
00617 # @param io Indicates whether or not to write the renumbered pedigree to a file (yes|no).
00618 # @param outformat Flag to indicate whether or not to write an asd pedigree (0) or a full pedigree (1).
00619 # @param returnmap Indicates whether or not an ID map, as well as the renumbered pedigree, should be returned.  If nonzero, suppresses writing of ID maps to disc.
00620 # @param debug Flag to indicate whether or not progress messages are written to stdout.
00621 # @param missingparent Indicates the value used to indicate a missing parent.
00622 # @param animaltype Type of animal object used to populate pedigree
00623 # @param cleanmap Cleans-up (deletes) the ID map file after renumbering is complete.
00624 # @retval A reordered PyPedal pedigree.
00625 def renumber(myped, filetag='_renumbered_', io='no', outformat='0', debug=0, returnmap=0, missingparent=0, \
00626     animaltype='new', cleanmap=True):
00627     """
00628     renumber() takes a pedigree as input and renumbers it such that the oldest
00629     animal in the pedigree has an ID of '1' and the n-th animal has an ID of 'n'.  If the
00630     pedigree is not ordered from oldest to youngest such that all offspring precede their
00631     offspring, the pedigree will be reordered.  The renumbered pedigree is written to
00632     disc in 'asd' format and a map file that associates sequential IDs with original IDs is also written.
00633     """
00634     if debug == 1:
00635         print '[DEBUG]: Pedigree of size %s passed to renumber()' % (len(myped))
00636 
00637     # Do we have NewAnimals? They have names and others do not.
00638     if animaltype == 'new': isnewanimal = 1
00639     else: isnewanimal = 0
00640 
00641     # In the dictionary id_map, the old IDs are the keys and the
00642     # new IDs are the values.
00643     id_map = {}
00644     idnum = 1       # starting ID number for renumbered IDs
00645     for l in xrange(len(myped)):
00646         if debug == 1:
00647             if l == 0:
00648                 print '[DEBUG]: Renumbering the pedigree...'
00649             if numpy.fmod(l,10000) == 0:
00650                 print'\t%s ' % (l)
00651             print '[DEBUG]: An:%s (%s)\tSire: %s\tDam: %s' % (myped[l].animalID,myped[l].paddedID,myped[l].sireID,myped[l].damID)
00652         id_map[myped[l].animalID] = idnum
00653         #myped[l].animalID = id_map[myped[l].animalID]
00654         if debug == 1:
00655             print '\t[DEBUG]: Renumbering animal from %s to %s (iter %s)' % (myped[l].animalID,idnum,l)
00656         myped[l].renumberedID = idnum
00657         myped[l].animalID = idnum
00658         # If an animal has its original ID as its name, we need
00659         # to change the name to match the renumbered ID so that
00660         # pedigree drawings using pyp_graphics/draw_pedigree()
00661         # will be correctly labelled.
00662         if isnewanimal:
00663             if myped[l].name == myped[l].originalID:
00664                 myped[l].name = myped[l].renumberedID
00665         # We cannot forget to renumber parents, too!
00666         s = myped[l].sireID
00667         if str(s) != str(missingparent):
00668         # This is a hack to deal with offspring that have birthdates which precede their parents'.
00669             try:
00670                 if debug == 1:
00671                     print '\t\t[DEBUG]: Renumbering sire from %s to %s' % (s,id_map[s])
00672                 myped[l].sireID = id_map[s]
00673             except:
00674                 myped[l].sireID = 0
00675         d = myped[l].damID
00676         if str(d) != str(missingparent):
00677         # This is a hack to deal with offspring that have birthdates which precede their parents'.
00678             try:
00679                 if debug == 1:
00680                     print '\t\t[DEBUG]: Renumbering dam from %s to %s' % (d,id_map[d])
00681                 myped[l].damID = id_map[d]
00682             except:
00683                 myped[l].damID = 0
00684         idnum = idnum + 1
00685         if debug == 1:
00686             print '[DEBUG]: animal ID = %s (%s)' % (myped[l].animalID, myped[l].originalID)
00687             print '[DEBUG]: An:%s\tSire: %s\tDam: %s' % (myped[l].animalID,myped[l].sireID,myped[l].damID)
00688         #print
00689 
00690     # This next bit renumbers the sons, daus, and unks dictionaries for
00691     # each animal.
00692     if isnewanimal:
00693         _sons, _daus, _unks = {}, {}, {}
00694         for m in myped:
00695             # Renumber sons
00696             for k in m.sons.keys():
00697                 try: _sons[id_map[k]] = k
00698                 except: pass
00699             m.sons = _sons
00700             # Renumber daughters
00701             for k in m.daus.keys():
00702                 try: _daus[id_map[k]] = k
00703                 except: pass
00704             m.daus = _daus
00705             # Renumber unknowns
00706             for k in m.unks.keys():
00707                 try: _unks[id_map[k]] = k
00708                 except: pass
00709             m.unks = _unks
00710 
00711     if io == 'yes':
00712         # Write the renumbered pedigree to a file
00713         ped_outputfile = '%s%s%s' % (filetag,'_renum','.ped')
00714         pout = open(ped_outputfile,'w')
00715         pname = '# FILE: %s\n' % (ped_outputfile)
00716         pout.write(pname)
00717         pout.write('# RENUMBERED pedigree produced by PyPedal.\n')
00718         pout.write('% asd\n')
00719         for l in range(len(myped)):
00720             if outformat == '0' or outformat == 0:
00721                 pout.write('%s,%s,%s\n' % myped[l].animalID,myped[l].sireID,myped[l].damID)
00722             else:
00723                 pout.write('%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s,%s\n' % myped[l].animalID,myped[l].sireID,myped[l].damID,myped[l].by,myped[l].sex,myped[l].fa,myped[l].gen)
00724         pout.close()
00725     if not returnmap:
00726         # Write the old ID -> new ID mapping to a file
00727         map_outputfile = '%s%s%s' % (filetag,'_id_map','.map')
00728         #print '[DEBUG]: ID map file name is %s' % (map_outputfile)
00729         mout = open(map_outputfile,'w')
00730         mname = '# FILE: %s\n' % (map_outputfile)
00731         mout.write(mname)
00732         mout.write('# Renumbered ID to Old ID mapping produced by PyPedal.\n')
00733         mout.write('# The lefthand column contains the original IDs.\n')
00734         mout.write('# The righthand column contains the renumbered IDs.\n')
00735         mout.write('# Old ID\tRenum ID\n')
00736         k = id_map.keys()
00737         v = id_map.values()
00738         for l in range(len(id_map)):
00739             mout.write('%s,%s\n' % (k[l],v[l]))
00740             #print 'Old ID = %s,  New ID = %s' % (k[l],v[l])
00741         mout.close()
00742     # Clean-up
00743     if cleanmap == True:
00744         delete_id_map(filetag)
00745     #print 'ID map in renumber():%s' % (id_map)
00746     if not returnmap:
00747         return myped
00748     else:
00749         return myped, id_map
00750 
00751 ##
00752 # load_id_map() reads an ID map from the file generated by pyp_utils/renumber()
00753 # into a dictionary.  There is a VERY similar function, pyp_io/id_map_from_file(), that
00754 # is deprecated because it is much more fragile that this procedure.
00755 # @param filetag A descriptor prepended to output file names that is used to determine the input file name.
00756 # @retval A dictionary whose keys are renumbered IDs and whose values are original IDs or an empty dictionary (on failure).
00757 def load_id_map(filetag='_renumbered_'):
00758     """
00759     load_id_map() reads an ID map from the file generated by pyp_utils/renumber()
00760     into a dictionary.  There is a VERY similar function, pyp_io/id_map_from_file(), that
00761     is deprecated because it is much more fragile that this procedure.
00762     """
00763     try:
00764         _infile = '%s%s%s' % (filetag,'_id_map','.map')
00765         mapin = open(_infile,'r')
00766         idmap = {}
00767         while 1:
00768             line = mapin.readline()
00769             if not line:
00770                 break
00771             else:
00772                 line = string.strip(line[:-1])
00773                 if line[0] == '#':
00774                     pass
00775                 else:
00776                     _line = string.split(line,',')
00777                     if len(_line) != 2:
00778                         print '[ERROR]: Invalid number of elements in line read from ID map file (%s)' % (_line)
00779                         break
00780                     else:
00781                         idmap[int(_line[1])] = int(_line[0])
00782         mapin.close()
00783         return idmap
00784     except:
00785         #print '[ERROR]: Could not open the ID map file %s in load_id_map()!' % (_infile)
00786         #sys.exit(0)
00787         return {}
00788 
00789 ##
00790 # delete_id_map() checks to see if an ID map for the given filetag exists.  If the file exists, it is
00791 # deleted.
00792 # @param filetag A descriptor prepended to output file names that is used to determine name of the file to delete.
00793 # @retval A flag indicating whether or not the file was successfully deleted (0|1)
00794 def delete_id_map(filetag='_renumbered_'):
00795     """
00796     delete_id_map() checks to see if an ID map for the given filetag exists.  If the file
00797     exists, it is deleted.
00798     """
00799     try:
00800         _infile = '%s%s%s' % (filetag,'_id_map','.map')
00801         if _infile in os.listdir('.'):
00802             os.remove(_infile)
00803         return 1
00804     except:
00805         return 0
00806 
00807 ##
00808 # trim_pedigree_to_year() takes pedigrees and removes all individuals who were not born
00809 # in birthyear 'year'.
00810 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree object.
00811 # @param year A birthyear.
00812 # @retval A pedigree containing only animals born in the given birthyear or an ampty list (on failure).
00813 def trim_pedigree_to_year(pedobj,year):
00814     """
00815     trim_pedigree_to_year() takes pedigrees and removes all individuals who were not born
00816     in birthyear 'year'.
00817     """
00818     # trim_pedigree_to_year() takes pedigrees and removes all individuals
00819     # who were not born in birthyear 'year'.  The reduced (trimmed) pedigree
00820     # is returned.
00821     try:
00822         indices = []
00823         modped = pedobj.pedigree[:]
00824         for l in range(len(modped)):
00825             if int(modped[l].by) == int(year):
00826                 pass
00827             else:
00828                 indices.append(l)
00829         indices.reverse()
00830         for i in range(len(indices)):
00831             del modped[indices[i]]
00832         return modped
00833     except:
00834         return []
00835 
00836 ##
00837 # pedigree_range() takes a renumbered pedigree and removes all individuals
00838 # with a renumbered ID > n.  The reduced pedigree is returned.  Assumes that
00839 # the input pedigree is sorted on animal key in ascending order.
00840 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree object.
00841 # @param n A renumbered animalID.
00842 # @retval A pedigree containing only animals born in the given birthyear of an ampty list (on failure).
00843 def pedigree_range(pedobj, n):
00844     """
00845     pedigree_range() takes a renumbered pedigree and removes all individuals
00846     with a renumbered ID > n.  The reduced pedigree is returned.  Assumes that
00847     the input pedigree is sorted on animal key in ascending order.
00848     """
00849     # pedigree_range() takes a renumbered pedigree and removes all individuals
00850     # with a renumbered ID > n.  The reduced pedigree is returned.  Assumes that
00851     # the input pedigree is sorted on animal key in ascending order.
00852     try:
00853         modped = []
00854         for i in range(n):
00855             modped.append(pedobj.pedigree[i])
00856             return modped
00857     except:
00858         return []
00859 
00860 ##
00861 # sort_dict_by_keys() returns a dictionary where the values in the dictionary
00862 # in the order obtained by sorting the keys.  Taken from the routine sortedDictValues3
00863 # in the "Python Cookbook", p. 39.
00864 # @param mydict A non-empty Python dictionary.
00865 # @retval The input dictionary with keys sorted in ascending order or an empty dictionary (on failure).
00866 def sort_dict_by_keys(mydict):
00867     """
00868     sort_dict_by_keys() returns a dictionary where the values in the dictionary
00869     in the order obtained by sorting the keys.  Taken from the routine sortedDictValues3
00870     in the "Python Cookbook", p. 39.
00871     """
00872     try:
00873         if len(mydict) == 0:
00874             return mydict
00875         else:
00876             keys = mydict.keys()
00877             keys.sort()
00878             return map(mydict.get, keys)
00879     except:
00880         return {}
00881 
00882 ##
00883 # sort_dict_by_values() returns a dictionary where the keys in the dictionary
00884 # are sorted ascending value, first on value and then on key within value.  The
00885 # implementation was taken from John Hunter's contribution to a newsgroup thread:
00886 # http://groups-beta.google.com/group/comp.lang.python/browse_thread/thread/bbc259f8454e4d3f/cc686f4cd795feb4?q=python+%22sorted+dictionary%22&rnum=1&hl=en#cc686f4cd795feb4
00887 # @param first Python list of dictionary keys.
00888 # @param second Python list of dictionary values.
00889 # @retval A list of tuples sorted in ascending order.
00890 def sort_dict_by_values(first, second):
00891     """
00892     sort_dict_by_values() returns a dictionary where the keys in the dictionary
00893     are sorted ascending value, first on value and then on key within value.  The
00894     implementation was taken from John Hunter's contribution to a newsgroup thread:
00895     http://groups-beta.google.com/group/comp.lang.python/browse_thread/thread
00896     /bbc259f8454e4d3f/cc686f4cd795feb4?q=python+%22sorted+dictionary%22&
00897     rnum=1&hl=en#cc686f4cd795feb4
00898     """
00899     c1 = cmp(first[1], second[1])
00900     if c1!=0:
00901         return c1
00902     return cmp(first[0], second[0])
00903 
00904 ##
00905 # simple_histogram_dictionary() returns a dictionary containing a simple, text histogram.
00906 # The input dictionary is assumed to contain keys which are distinct levels and values
00907 # that are counts.
00908 # @param mydict A non-empty Python dictionary.
00909 # @param histchar The character used to draw the histogram (default is '*').
00910 # @param histstep Used to determine the number of bins (stars) in the diagram.
00911 # @retval A dictionary containing the histogram by level or an empty dictionary (on failure).
00912 def simple_histogram_dictionary(mydict, histchar='*', histstep=5):
00913     """
00914     simple_histogram_dictionary() returns a dictionary containing a simple, text
00915     histogram.  The input dictionary is assumed to contain keys which are distinct levels
00916     and values that are counts.
00917     """
00918     try:
00919         hist_dict = {}
00920         hist_sum = 0.
00921         if histstep < 0 or histstep > 100:
00922             histstep = 5
00923         for k in mydict.keys():
00924             hist_sum = hist_sum + mydict[k]
00925         #print '[DEBUG]: %s' % (hist_sum)
00926         for k in mydict.keys():
00927             _freq = ( float(mydict[k]) / float(hist_sum) ) * 100.
00928             _v = around(_freq,0)
00929             _n_stars = int( around( (_v / float(histstep)),0 ) )
00930             if _n_stars > 0:
00931                 hist_dict[k] = '%s%s' % (histchar*_n_stars,' '*(20-_n_stars))
00932             else:
00933                 hist_dict[k] = '%s' % (' '*20)
00934         return hist_dict
00935     except:
00936         return {}
00937 
00938 ##
00939 # reverse_string() reverses the input string and returns the reversed version.
00940 # @param mystring A non-empty Python string.
00941 # @retval The input string with the order of its characters reversed.
00942 def reverse_string(mystring):
00943     """
00944     reverse_string() reverses the input string and returns the reversed version.
00945     """
00946     try:
00947         if len(mystring) < 2:
00948             return mystring
00949         else:
00950             mystringreversed = []
00951             for l in range(len(mystring)):
00952                 mystringreversed.append(mystring[l])
00953                 mystringreversed.reverse().join()
00954             return mystringreversed
00955     except:
00956         return 0
00957 
00958 ##
00959 # pyp_nice_time() returns the current date and time formatted as, e.g.,
00960 # Wed Mar 30 10:26:31 2005.
00961 # @retval A string containing the formatted date and time.
00962 def pyp_nice_time():
00963     """
00964     pyp_nice_time() returns the current date and time formatted as, e.g.,
00965     Wed Mar 30 10:26:31 2005.
00966     """
00967     try:
00968         return time.asctime(time.localtime(time.time()))
00969     except:
00970         return 0
00971 
00972 ##
00973 # string_to_table_name() takes an arbitrary string and returns a string that
00974 # is safe to use as an SQLite table name.
00975 # @param instring A string that will be converted to an SQLite-safe table name.
00976 # @retval A string that is safe to use as an SQLite table name.
00977 def string_to_table_name(instring):
00978     """
00979     string_to_table_name() takes an arbitrary string and returns a string that
00980     is safe to use as an SQLite table name.
00981     """
00982     try:
00983         # This list comprehension idea is taken from the Python Cookbook:
00984         # http://aspn.activestate.com/ASPN/Cookbook/Python/Recipe/59857
00985         allowed_chars = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ0123456789_'
00986         outstring = ''.join([c for c in instring if c in allowed_chars])
00987         return outstring
00988     except:
00989         return instring
00990 
00991 ##
00992 # pyp_datestamp() returns a datestamp, as a string, of the format
00993 # YYYYMMDDHHMMSS.
00994 # @retval A 14-character string containing the datestamp.
00995 def pyp_datestamp():
00996     """
00997     pyp_datestamp() returns a datestamp, as a string, of the format
00998     YYYYMMDDHHMMSS.
00999     """
01000     try:
01001         #return time.asctime(time.localtime(time.time()))
01002         return time.strftime('%Y%m%d%H%M%S', (time.localtime(time.time())))
01003     except:
01004         return '00000000000000'

01006 ##
01007 # subpedigree() takes a NewPedigree object and list of animal
01008 # IDs and returns a NewPedigree object containing only the
01009 # animals in the animals list.
01010 # @param pedobj PyPedal pedigree object.
01011 # @param anlist A list of animal IDs.
01012 # @retval An instance of a NewPedigree object.
01013 def subpedigree(pedobj, anlist):
01014     """
01015     subpedigree() takes a NewPedigree object and list of animal
01016     IDs and returns a NewPedigree object containing only the
01017     animals in the animals list.
01018     """
01019     try:
01020         NewPed = copy.copy(pedobj)
01021         order = []
01022         _tempped = copy.copy(NewPed.pedigree)
01023         for _p in _tempped:
01024             order.append(_p.animalID)
01025         for _p in NewPed.pedigree:
01026             if _p.animalID not in anlist:
01027                 # Delete the animal from the pedigree and the
01028                 # ID maps.
01029                 _anidx = order.index(_p.animalID)
01030                 del NewPed.namemap[NewPed.namebackmap[NewPed.backmap[_p.animalID]]]
01031                 del NewPed.namebackmap[NewPed.backmap[_p.animalID]]
01032                 del NewPed.idmap[NewPed.backmap[_p.animalID]]
01033                 del NewPed.backmap[_p.animalID]
01034                 del _tempped[_anidx]
01035                 del order[_anidx]
01036                 for _t in _tempped:
01037                     order.append(_t.animalID)
01038         # Update the metadata object.
01039         NewPed.pedigree = _tempped
01040         del(_tempped)
01041         del(order)
01042         NewPed.metadata = pyp_newclasses.PedigreeMetadata(NewPed.pedigree, NewPed.kw)
01043         # Renumber the pedigree.
01044         if NewPed.kw['renumber']:
01045             NewPed.renumber()
01046         return NewPed
01047     except:
01048         return 0
01049 
01050 ##
01051 # founders_from_list() takes a list of NewAnimal objects and returns a
01052 # list of animalIDs that represent founders in that pedigree (animals
01053 # with an unknown sire and dam.
01054 # @param anlist A list of NewAnimal objects.
01055 # @param unkID The animalID assigned to unknown parents.
01056 # @retval A list of animalIDs of founders.
01057 def founders_from_list(anlist, unkID):
01058     """
01059     founders_from_list() takes a list of NewAnimal objects and returns a
01060     list of animalIDs that represent founders in that pedigree (animals
01061     with an unknown sire and dam.
01062     """
01063     try:
01064         flist = [x.animalID for x in anlist if x.sireID == unkID and x.damID == unkID]
01065         return flist
01066     except:
01067         return []
01068 
01069 ##
01070 # founder_allele_dict() takes a pedigree and returns a dictionary containing
01071 # an entry for each unique founder allele.
01072 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree.
01073 # @retval A dictionary whose keys are founder alleles and whose values are 0.0
01074 def founder_allele_dict(pedobj):
01075     """
01076     founder_allele_dict() takes a pedigree and returns a dictionary containing
01077     an entry for each unique founder allele.
01078     """
01079     try:
01080         falist = [pedobj.pedigree[x-1].alleles for x in pedobj.metadata.unique_founder_list]
01081         fadict = {}
01082         for fa in falist:
01083             fadict[fa[0]] = 0.
01084             fadict[fa[1]] = 0.
01085         return fadict
01086     except:
01087         return {}
01088 
01089 ##
01090 # founder_allele_map() takes a pedigree and returns a dictionary
01091 # mapping founder alleles to their animal of origin.
01092 # @note I don't remember writing this, so I'm not sure just what I intended it to do. Probably broken.
01093 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree.
01094 # @retval A dictionary whose keys are founder alleles and whose values are the founder of origin.
01095 def founder_allele_map(pedobj):
01096     """
01097     founder_allele_map() takes a pedigree and returns a dictionary
01098     mapping founder alleles to their animal of origin.
01099     """
01100     try:
01101         falist = [pedobj.pedigree[x-1].alleles for x in pedobj.metadata.unique_founder_list]
01102         fadict = {}
01103         for fa in falist:
01104             fadict[fa[0]] = None
01105             fadict[fa[1]] = None
01106         fakeys = fadict.keys()
01107         for fa in fakeys:
01108             fadict[fa] = fakeys.index(fa)
01109         return fadict
01110     except:
01111         return {}

01113 ##
01114 # founder_allele_freq() takes a pedigree and returns a dictionary containing
01115 # an entry for each unique founder allele and the frequency of that allele in
01116 # a list of provided animals.
01117 # @note I don't remember writing this, so I'm not sure just what I intended it to do. Probably broken.
01118 # @param pedobj A PyPedal pedigree.
01119 # @param anlist A list of animals in which to track founder allele frequencies.
01120 # @param allele_map Dictionary mapping founder alleles to their animal of origin.
01121 # @param allele_mat Dictionary counting founder alleles.
01122 # @param column Select the correct column to increment.
01123 # @retval A dictionary whose keys are founder alleles and whose values are frequencies.
01124 def founder_allele_freq(pedobj, anlist, allele_map, allele_mat, column):
01125     """
01126     founder_allele_freq() takes a pedigree and returns a dictionary containing
01127     an entry for each unique founder allele and the frequency of that allele in
01128     a list of provided animals.
01129     """
01130     #try:
01131     backmap = [pedobj.idmap[an] for an in anlist]
01132     fafreq = [pedobj.pedigree[an-1].alleles for an in backmap]
01133     for fa in fafreq:
01134         row0 = allele_map[fa[0]]
01135         row1 = allele_map[fa[1]]
01136         #print '    Adding 1 to row %s, col %s' % ( row0, column )
01137         allele_mat[row0,column] = allele_mat[row0,column] + 1.
01138         #print '    Adding 1 to row %s, col %s' % ( row1, column )
01139         allele_mat[row1,column] = allele_mat[row1,column] + 1.
01140     return allele_mat
01141     #except:
01142     #    return False

01144 ##
01145 # list_intersection() returns a PyPedal pedigree object which contains the animals that are common to
01146 # both input pedigrees. If there are no animals in common between the two pedgrees, a value
01147 # of false is returned.
01148 # @param pedobjs A list of PyPedal pedigrees.
01149 # @retval A new PyPedal pedigree containing the animals that are common to both input pedigrees.
01150 def list_intersection(pedobjs):
01151     """
01152     list_intersection() returns a PyPedal pedigree object which contains the animals that are common to
01153     both input pedigrees. If there are no animals in common between the two pedgrees, a value
01154     of false is returned.
01155     """
01156     if len(pedobjs) > 0:
01157         if pedobjs[0].kw['debug_messages']:
01158             print '[INFO]: Computing intersection of %s pedigrees' % ( len(pedobjs) )
01159                 logging.info('Computing intersection of %s pedigrees', len(pedobjs))
01160         plen = len(pedobjs)
01161         # If there is only one pedigree in the list this is easy: A \cap A = A.
01162         if plen == 1:
01163             return pedobjs[0]
01164         # If there is more than one pedigree in the list we use the following factorization
01165         # to compute the intersection of those pedigrees:
01166         #
01167         # A \cap B \cap C \cap D ... Y \cap Z = (A \cap (B \cap (C \cap (D \cap ... (Y \cap Z) ) ) ) )
01168         #
01169         # See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersection_%28set_theory%29).
01170         else:
01171             intersected = pyp_newclasses.loadPedigree({'pedfile':'null'}, pedsource='null')
01172             for p in range(plen-1, -1, -1):
01173                 if pedobjs[p].__class__.__name__ != 'NewPedigree':
01174                     if pedobjs[0].kw['debug_messages']:
01175                         print '[ERROR]: Pedigree %s in pyp_utils.list_intersection() is not a NewPedigree instance! Skippng.' % ( p )
01176                     logging.error('Pedigree %s in pyp_utils.list_intersection() is not a NewPedigree instance! Skippng.', p)
01177                 else:
01178                     intersected = intersected.intersection(pedobjs[p])
01179         return intersected
01180     else:
01181         logging.error('An empty list was passed to pyp_utils/list_intersection()! Cannot compute intersection on 0 pedigrees.')
01182 
01183 ##
01184 # list_union() returns a PyPedal pedigree object which contains all animals included in both of the
01185 # input pedigrees.
01186 # @param pedobjs A list of PyPedal pedigrees.
01187 # @retval A new PyPedal pedigree containing the animals that are common to both input pedigrees.
01188 def list_union(pedobjs):
01189     """
01190     list_union() returns a PyPedal pedigree object which contains all animals included in both of the
01191     input pedigrees.
01192     """
01193     if len(pedobjs) > 0:
01194         logging.info('Computing union of %s pedigrees', len(pedobjs))
01195         for p in range(len(pedobjs)):
01196             # The first time through create a null (empty) pedigree and use it to build-up
01197             # the union of the input pedigrees.
01198             if p == 0:
01199                 new_pedigree = pyp_newclasses.loadPedigree({'pedfile':'null'}, pedsource='null')
01200             if pedobjs[p].__class__.__name__ != 'NewPedigree':
01201                 logging.info('Pedigree %s in pyp_utils.list_union() is not a NewPedigree instance! Skippng.', p)
01202             # Renumber the input pedigrees, if necessary, and compute the union of new_pedigree and
01203             # the first entry in the pedobjs list. new_pedigree starts out as an empty (null)
01204             # pedigree, and each valid input pedigree is added to that to build-up the union of
01205             # all of the inputs.
01206             else:
01207                 logging.info('Using match rule %s to compare pedigrees', pedobjs[p].kw['match_rule'])
01208                 # Pedigrees must be renumbered
01209                 if p > 0 and new_pedigree.kw['pedigree_is_renumbered'] != 1:
01210                     new_pedigree.renumber()
01211                     logging.info('Renumbering pedigree %s', new_pedigree.kw['pedname'])
01212                 if pedobjs[p].kw['pedigree_is_renumbered'] != 1:
01213                             pedobjs[p].renumber()
01214                             logging.info('Renumbering pedigree %s', pedobjs[p].kw['pedname'])
01215                 # Compute the union of new_pedigree and the current entry in pedobjs using
01216                 # the NewPedigree::__add__() method.
01217                 try:
01218                     new_pedigree = new_pedigree + pedobjs[p]
01219                 except:
01220                     logging.error('Could not compute union of input pedigrees.')
01221                     return False
01222         # Once we've looped all the way through pedobjs we can return the new pedigree.
01223         return new_pedigree
01224     else:
01225         logging.error('Cannot complete union operation because types do not match.')
01226         return NotImplemented
01227 
01228 ##
01229 # guess_pedformat() tries to guess the pedigree format code that best matches a NewAnimal instance provided as
01230 # input based on the animal attributes as comapared to the default missing values for those attributes. I know
01231 # that you're wondering why we can't just use the pedformat that's in the pedigree options dictionary, and it's
01232 # because this is intended primarily for use with functions that take as input NewAnimal objects which may come
01233 # from different pedigrees with different pedformats. Note that the logic of guess_pedformat() depends entirely
01234 # on the single NewAnimal passed as input. If you make a judicious (read: lucky) choice, then you can feel pretty
01235 # good about the result. Otherwise, you may want to call guess_pedformat() several times with different inputs
01236 # to develop a consensus pedformat.
01237 # @param animal A NewAnimal instance.
01238 # @param ped_kw The kw dictionary from a NewPedigree object.
01239 # @retval A string containing the best-guess pedformat, or False.
01240 def guess_pedformat(animal, ped_kw):
01241     """
01242     guess_pedformat() tries to guess the pedigree format code that best matches a NewAnimal instance provided
01243     as input based on the animal attributes as comapared to the default missing values for those attributes.
01244     I know that you're wondering why we can't just use the pedformat that's in the pedigree options dictionary,
01245     and it's because this is intended primarily for use with functions that take as input NewAnimal objects
01246     which may come from different pedigrees with different pedformats. Note that the logic of guess_pedformat()
01247     depends entirely on the single NewAnimal passed as input. If you make a judicious (read: lucky) choice, then
01248     you can feel pretty good about the result. Otherwise, you may want to call guess_pedformat() several times
01249     with different inputs to develop a consensus pedformat.
01250     """
01251     if animal.__class__.__name__ == 'NewAnimal':
01252         # Loop over each NewAnimal attribute and check to see if it's been assigned a
01253         # missing value. 
01254         pedformat = ''
01255         # The following code differentiates between 'asd' and 'ASD' formats. Recall
01256         # that a pedigree must be 'asd' or 'ASD', you can't mix types of animal,
01257         # sire, and dam names. Consequently, we only need to figure out if the
01258         # animal ID was originally a string or an integer.
01259         if isinstance(animal.originalID, int):
01260             pedformat = 'asd'
01261         elif isinstance(animal.originalID, str):
01262             pedformat = 'ASD'
01263         else:
01264             logging.error('pyp_utils/guess_pedformat() cannot process animal.originalID if it is not a string or an integer type!')
01265             if ped_kw['messages'] == 'verbose':
01266                 print '[ERROR]: pyp_utils/guess_pedformat() cannot process animal.originalID if it is not a string or an integer type!'
01267             return False
01268         # Now figure out other attributes.
01269         if animal.bd != ped_kw['missing_bdate']: pedformat.append('b')
01270         if animal.by != ped_kw['missing_byear']: pedformat.append('y')
01271         if animal.name != ped_kw['missing_name']: pedformat.append('n')
01272         if animal.breed != ped_kw['missing_nreed']: pedformat.append('r')
01273         if animal.herd != ped_kw['missing_herd']: pedformat.append('H')
01274         if animal.sex != ped_kw['missing_sex']: pedformat.appenx('x')
01275         if animal.fa != ped_kw['missing_inbreeding']: pedformat.append('f')
01276         if animal.alive != ped_kw['missing_alive']: pedformat.append('l')
01277         if animal.age != ped_kw['missing_age']: pedformat.append('e')
01278         if animal.gen != ped_kw['missing_gen']: pedformat.append('g')
01279         if animal.gencoeff != ped_kw['missing_gencoeff']: pedformat.append('p')
01280         if animal.alleles != ped_kw['missing_alleles']: pedformat.append('L')
01281         if animal.userField != ped_kw['missing_userfield']: pedformat.append('u')
01282         # Let the user know what's going on (at the top of my lungs).
01283         logging.info('The best-guess pedformat is: \'%s\'', pedformat)
01284         if ped_kw['messages'] == 'verbose':
01285             print '[INFO]: The best-guess pedformat is: \'%s\'' % (pedformat)
01286         return pedformat
01287     else:
01288         logging.error('You passed an item to pyp_utils/guess_pedformat() that is not a NewAnimal!')
01289         if ped_kw['messages'] == 'verbose':
01290             print '[ERROR]: You passed an item to pyp_utils/guess_pedformat() that is not a NewAnimal!'
01291 
01292         return False
